Exotica has always been one of those
musical styles that gets little
attention. Perhaps a little unfairly
lumped in with easy listening - you can
usually find old albums sitting side by
side with dodgy organ records and
covers albums in charity shops - it was
something of a boom industry in the
1950s. This excellent collection of
rare, obscure and little known 1950s
exotica from the Captain High label
tells the story of the genre's
gestation and boom, showcasing its'
links with jazz, traditional Hawaiian
and Polynesian styles and, of course,
easy listening. It's a rather wonderful
collection, all told, where tribal
drums and lilting pedal steel sit side
by side with monkey noises, parrot
squawks, odd spoken word interludes and
lashings of original vinyl crackle.

psst, more info at captain-high-records.com
